Major NATO countries like **the UK, France, Germany** rarely use the term "offset", but they ensure domestic industry involvement via other means. For example, the **British** when buying the American **F-35** became a Tier-1 development partner, securing significant production work for UK industry (British companies build \~15% of each F-35) - effectively an industrial benefit arrangement akin to offsets, but structured as partnership. **France** almost always buys domestically or jointly develops (so offsets as such don't apply since they favor domestic procurement). **Germany** similarly often co-develops (e.g. with European partners) or, if buying off-the-shelf, might request some final assembly domestically (as it did for some UAV imports). **Italy** and **Spain** have used offsets when buying from the US - for instance, Italy's C-130J purchase in early 2000s had an offset involving Italian firms making subassemblies for Lockheed.

The EU's crackdown on formal offsets means that since 2010, any **EU member's defence ministry** can't explicitly make offset a tender award criterion (except under national security exception)[\[42\]](@ianakiev_defence_2014#:~:text=Directive%2C%20its%20introduction%20will%20have,presence%20of%20the%20Directive%20will)[\[41\]](@ianakiev_defence_2014#:~:text=of%20the%20Treaty%2C%20the%20Directive,new%20legal%20framework%20equally%20rules). Instead, they use terms like "industrial return" or require bidders to include a plan for local involvement (subject to separate negotiation). Despite this, informal offsets persist in Europe - especially with non-EU suppliers. For example, **Finland** and **Switzerland** (not EU, but Western) demanded heavy offsets for their fighter jet buys in the 1990s. Even in 2021, Finland's \\\$9B F-35 purchase included industrial cooperation commitments (like engine maintenance facility in Finland) though Finland avoided calling it offsets due to EU rules.

**Canada** has one of the oldest offset regimes among Western nations, known historically as **Industrial & Regional Benefits (IRB)**. Since **1986**, Canada required that any major defence procurement from foreign suppliers results in investments in Canada equal to the contract value (100% offset)[\[117\]](https://natoassociation.ca/a-made-in-canada-defence-industrial-policy-the-industrial-and-technological-benefits-policy/#:~:text=A%20Made%20in%20Canada%20Defence,2014%2C%20which%20required%20defence). This was partly to appease domestic politics - ensuring all regions of Canada got economic spin-offs from big purchases (for instance, the CF-18 fighter buy in the 1980s brought aerospace work to multiple provinces). In 2014, Canada revamped IRB into the **Industrial and Technological Benefits (ITB)** policy[\[118\]](https://www.wd-deo.gc.ca/eng/19833.asp#:~:text=...%20www.wd,IRB%29%20Policy). The ITB policy still mandates 100% economic benefit, but now puts emphasis on priority areas and a "value proposition" where bidders are graded on how their proposal will provide long-term technological benefit to Canada[\[119\]](https://www.canada.ca/en/innovation-science-economic-development/news/2017/04/the_industrial_andtechnologicalbenefitspolicy.html#:~:text=Originally%20known%20as%20the%20Industrial,Policy%20was%20launched). The **outcomes** have been significant in sustaining Canada's aerospace industry: companies like Magellan and CAE grew through offset-related subcontracts (making components for Airbus, Boeing, etc., as a result of past offset obligations). However, critics note that many IRB projects were essentially **indirect offsets** (investments in auto parts or other industries) that did not build a self-sufficient defence industry. Canada still relies on imports for most major systems, but it has carved a niche in training simulators, avionics, and space tech, thanks in part to past offsets. Notably, Canada's policy is very formal and transparent - companies regularly report their Canadian content and investments, and there are even cases of companies *over-performing* (exceeding offset requirements) to win favor for future deals[\[120\]](https://www.emergingtechnologies.ca/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/Canadian-ITB-Guide_HP-June-2022-Windsor.pdf#:~:text=,Ensures%20that%20defence%20equipment).

**Australia** historically did not use the term offsets as mentioned, but in earlier decades it had an "Australian Industry Involvement" policy for defence. In the 2000s, it shifted to the **AIC (Australian Industry Capability)** framework, requiring bidders to outline how they will include Australian suppliers. The government does not set a fixed percentage, but major projects like the **F-35, P-8, and naval ship builds** have seen substantial local work content (e.g. Australia locally builds parts of the F-35 and will build most of its new frigates domestically). The Australian stance is that strict offsets add cost premiums of 5-20%, which they want to avoid[\[40\]](https://parbery.com.au/making-it-stick-overcoming-the-impediments-to-delivering-on-defences-australian-industry-capability-aspirations/#:~:text=,such%20arrangements%20in%20favour), but at the same time they invest heavily in domestic capability through other means (like teaming arrangements and direct subsidies to industry).

In summary, Western countries' experience with offsets is varied: **some smaller nations** that are net importers have used them to support their economies (with mixed success), whereas **larger defence producers** focus more on partnership and co-development. Many Western governments share the view that while offsets can bring short-term jobs, they can also distort the market and raise prices[\[12\]](@brauer_arms_2004%20#:~:text=Accordingly%2C%20the%20starting%20point%20for,will%20be%20trade%20diversion%2C%20trade)[\[40\]](https://parbery.com.au/making-it-stick-overcoming-the-impediments-to-delivering-on-defences-australian-industry-capability-aspirations/#:~:text=,such%20arrangements%20in%20favour). This is why bodies like the WTO and EU discourage them. Even the United States, the world's top arms exporter, has an official policy that views offsets as "market distorting" - but U.S. companies nonetheless engage in offsets because *not doing so would mean losing contracts* to European or other competitors who will offer them[\[45\]](@dehoff_defense_2014#:~:text=Western%20defense%20companies%20looking%20to,compensation%20arrangements%20with%20foreign%20governments)[\[121\]](@dehoff_defense_2014#:~:text=nondomestic%20suppliers,sales%20relationships%20in%20foreign%20markets). The U.S. requires contractors to report all offset agreements to the Department of Commerce, which publishes an annual report on offsets in defense trade (indicating tens of billions in obligations are active at any time)[\[122\]](@dehoff_defense_2014#:~:text=Although%20they%20are%20not%20usually,Guy). That data shows U.S. firms from 1993-2012 entered about \\\$70B in offset agreements, mainly to Europe and the Middle East[\[122\]](@dehoff_defense_2014#:~:text=Although%20they%20are%20not%20usually,Guy).

Thus, even in Western supplier nations, offsets have indirectly shaped the industry by pushing companies to globalize their supply chains - sometimes outsourcing work to the buying country's factories (which in some cases are subsidiaries or joint ventures of the same company). The line between offsets and normal business blurs here, echoing Hall and Markowski's point that an offset is ultimately a part of a larger complex transaction[\[123\]](@brauer_arms_2004%20#:~:text=%E2%80%9COffsets%20are%20simply%20goods%20and,179)[\[124\]](@brauer_arms_2004%20#:~:text=The%20jab%E2%80%94that%20offsets%20are%20%E2%80%9Cthose,%E2%80%9Cprimary%20contract%E2%80%9D%20and%20that%20which). The difference is perspective: economists may frown upon it, but as long as buyer governments **"universally acknowledge"** their benefits in securing domestic political support[\[125\]](https://www.rusi.org/explore-our-research/publications/commentary/implementation-indias-defence-offset-policy#:~:text=streamlined%20regulatory%20environment), offsets or their equivalents will remain a fixture of defence procurement.
